CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll provide a clear explanation.</think>We will show one acceptable way to “read‐off” the functions f(n) and g(n) from the identities

  kₙ = n·f(n) + g(n)

once you know some numerical values for kₙ. (In what follows we assume that when a division is not exact we define f(n) to be the quotient obtained by “integer‐division” of kₙ by n; note that in other contexts one might instead work with fractional parts.) 

For example, suppose that you know

  k₇ = 76,
  k₈ = 224,
  k₉ = 467,
  k₁₁ = 1155, and
  k₁₂ = 2683.

Then writing kₙ in the form

  kₙ = n·f(n) + g(n)

we may “read‐off” f(n) as follows:

• For n = 7 we have
  76 = 7 · f(7) + g(7).
Dividing 76 by 7 gives 10 with remainder 6. That is,
  f(7) = 10  and g(7) = 6.

• For n = 8 we have
  224 = 8 · f(8) + g(8).
Since 224 divided by 8 is exactly 28, we get
  f(8) = 28  and g(8) = 0.

• For n = 9 we have
  467 = 9 · f(9) + g(9).
Dividing 467 by 9 gives 51 with remainder 8 (because 9×51 = 459 and 467 – 459 = 8). Thus,
  f(9) = 51  and g(9) = 8.

• For n = 11 we have
  1155 = 11 · f(11) + g(11).
Since 1155 divided by 11 is exactly 105 (because 11×105 = 1155), we obtain
  f(11) = 105  and g(11) = 0.

• For n = 12 we have
  2683 = 12 · f(12) + g(12).
Dividing 2683 by 12 gives 223 with remainder 7 (since 12×223 = 2676 and 2683 – 2676 = 7). That is,
  f(12) = 223  and g(12) = 7.

There is one additional relation given by the problem, namely

  k₁₂ = k₈·12 − 5.
Notice that if you compute 224×12 – 5 you get
  2688 − 5 = 2683,
so this is just another way of writing k₁₂. (It shows that sometimes the formulas for the keys involve other keys.)

Thus one acceptable answer is to list the values as follows:

  f(7) = 10, f(8) = 28, f(9) = 51, f(11) = 105, and f(12) = 223.

Any answer that shows how to recover f(n) from the identities

  kₙ = n·f(n) + g(n)
by “dividing out” the factor of n is correct. (In our case we have chosen to take the quotient as the integer part of kₙ/n.) 

This completes one acceptable solution.
